Title: Gauss Sums of Cubic Characters
AcceptedAnswer: This result can be found in the reference book "H. Hasse, Vorlesungen über Zahlentheorie, 1950. P460/P461" But this book is in Germany and I cannot find it on line. Can someone show me a brief proof or a reference link in English to explain this result? See Ireland, Rosen. A Classical Introduction to Modern Number Theory, 9.12 (pp. 131-132). Brief summary: $G=g+\bar g$ where $g$ is a cubic Gauss sum is your $t$ up to something simple ( $G=3t-1$ , if I'm not wrong); $|g|=\sqrt p$ and $g^3=p\pi$ for $p=\pi\bar\pi$ in Eisenstein integers (this is standard, see e.g. ch.8 of the same book); so $G^3=g^3+\bar g^3+3g\bar g(g+\bar g)=p(\pi+\bar\pi)+3pG$ finally, your $a$ is equal to $\pi+\bar\pi$ .

###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
$p$ is a prime number,
$p \equiv 1 \mod 6$,
$g$ is a primitive root modulo $p$,
$H$ is the subgroup generated by $g^3$ in $\mathbb{F}_p^\times$,
$\zeta = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{p}}$,
There exist integers $a$ and $b$ such that $4p = a^2 + 27b^2$,
$a \equiv 1 \mod 3$ and $b > 0$.
Problem: 
Prove that the sums $t_1 = \sum_{x \in H} \zeta^x$, $t_2 = \sum_{x \in gH} \zeta^x$, and $t_3 = \sum_{x \in g^2H} \zeta^x$ are roots of the polynomial $$t^3 + t^2 - \frac{p-1}{3}t - \frac{ap + 3p - 1}{27}.$$
###

###BEGIN_OF_FORMAT###
Assumption: 
$p = 9p'$ where $p' = 1$ or $p'$ is a prime,
$p' \equiv 1 \mod 6$ if $p'$ is a prime,
$\varphi(p) = 6$ when $p' = 1$ and $\varphi(p) = 6(p'-1)$ when $p'$ is a prime,
The multiplicative group $(\mathbb{Z}/p\mathbb{Z})^\times$ is isomorphic to $\mathrm{C}_{p'-1} \times \mathrm{C}_6$ when $p'$ is a prime,
The integers coprime to $p$ are partitioned into three subgroups $H_1, H_2, H_3$,
$\zeta = e^{\frac{2\pi i}{p}}$,
There exist integers $a$ and $b$ such that $4p = a^2 + 27b^2$,
$a \equiv 0 \mod 3$.
Problem: 
Prove that the sums $t_1 = \sum_{x \in H_1} \zeta^x$, $t_2 = \sum_{x \in H_2} \zeta^x$, and $t_3 = \sum_{x \in H_3} \zeta^x$ are roots of the polynomial $$t^3 - \frac{p}{3}t - \frac{ap}{27}.$$
